intro: Loxocarya cinerea, commonly known as the grayleaf thistle, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its gray-green, fuzzy leaves and spiny, spherical flower heads that bloom in the summer. The plant belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its composite flowers made up of many tiny florets. Loxocarya cinerea typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and sagebrush steppe. Its unique appearance and ecological role make it an important component of its native ecosystem.
